citation.article-title: Isolation and characterization of a unique group of slowly growing mycobacteria: description of Mycobacterium lentiflavum sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Mycobacterium lentiflavum sp. nov.
Mycobacterium lentiflavum (lat.len.ti.fla.vum for slow and yellow, two characteristic features of this species)
Mycobacterium lentiflavum is an acid- and alcohol-fast, rod-shaped coccobacillus.
It does not form spores, a capsule, or aerial hyphae.
Visible growth from a dilute inoculum requires 3 to 4 weeks; colonies on LJ agar are smooth and 1 to 2 mm in diameter and show bright yellow pigmentation.
Growth occurs at temperatures between 22 and 378C.
The organism shows variable results in tests for semiquantitative catalase, heat-stable catalase, and pyrazinamidase.
It is negative in tests for niacin production, nitrate reduction, Tween hydrolysis, arylsulfatase, and urease.
The G+C content (determined for isolate 439/93) is 66.8 mol%.
M. lentiflavum synthesizes α-mycolates, α'-mycolates, and ketomycolates.

Phylogenetic analysis, based on an evaluation of 16S rRNA sequences, places M. lentiflavum in an intermediate position between rapidly and slowly growing mycobacteria, closely related to M. simiae and M. genavense.
The taxonomic level of separation as a distinct species is supported by DNA homology studies.
The type strain of M. lentiflavum is 2186/92, which was isolated from a patient with spondylodiscitis.
Cultures of strains 2186/92, 89-1002, 89-446, and 439/93 have been deposited in the American Type Culture Collection as strains ATCC 51985, 51987, 51988, and 51986, respectively.
